title: Never mind caveat emptor, it's time for some sponsor venditor
text:
Our energy provider had relied on the likelihood that we wouldn’t notice the price difference. And we nearly didn’t.

To date, I haven’t had the heart to look at our house, car, life or health insurance premiums, superannuation, telco contracts or mortgage.

Why should consumers expect better treatment from their banks and their energy providers?

Most of our day-to-day purchases are discrete transactions (think: lattes or shoes). Other purchases involve repeat or habitual transactions. By contrast, our inescapable need for energy and banking forces us into ongoing relationships with our providers. Critically, these relationships continue without our conscious effort.

We don’t transact with banks and energy companies. We have ongoing relationships with them. Successful relationships are based on trust.

My bank and energy provider may not have breached the law, but they certainly breached the trust I'd placed in them. They dishonoured the implied tenets of our relationship. Like millions of other energy and banking customers, I felt betrayed.

To date, the predominant regulatory response has been to implement measures that help customers shop around if they feel sufficiently betrayed by such breaches of trust.

This response is flawed: morally and economically.

Advertisement

It allows energy providers and banks to act with regulatory impunity in the hope their customers won't notice. These providers bear no responsibility for breaches of trust. Instead, customers are held responsible for failing to notice. That is not how healthy relationships work, commercial or otherwise.

Even worse, this regulatory response punishes customers by imposing on them the search and transaction costs of finding a new service provider – hopefully one they can trust. But how would they know?

This regulatory approach inverts the logic of markets. It places no regulatory value on trust. Instead, it sanctions breaches of trust and it imposes dead weight costs on consumers thereby undermining the efficiency of these markets.

The well-established legal principle of caveat emptor (buyer beware) may be acceptable in transactional markets, but it is inadequate in markets that rely on ongoing relationships such as energy and banking.

The time has come for a new principle to guide the regulation of these markets.

Let’s call this new principle ‘sponsor venditor’, loosely translated as: seller take responsibility.

This principle would hold banks and energy providers responsible for good customer outcomes. Such outcomes would not be contingent on customers noticing breaches of trust. Rather, banks and energy providers would be legally responsible for guaranteeing the good faith of their customers.

Banks and energy providers would be responsible for delivering service outcomes their customers judge to be fair and reasonable, rather than outcomes that merely satisfy their regulators.

Advertisement

To be clear, sponsor venditor would not mean more regulation. If designed well, it would mean less regulation, possibly much less regulation, as it would do away with the current mishmash of ad hoc consumer protections.

Another inquiry won’t tell us anything we don’t already know.

After everything we have learnt about energy and banking over the past year or two, let's seize the moment for genuine reform. Consumers deserve no less.

Ron Ben-David is former chairman of Victoria’s economic regulator, the Essential Services Commission.
description: No more buyer beware. Making the seller take responsibility should be the principle behind consumer regulation.
